p.s: In the play Disgraced, Scene 3 by Ayad Akhtar, Amir is the potagonistprotagonist.
He is around 40 years old and his parents are from Pakistan.
Amir lives an affluent livestylelifestyle with his wife, Emily, due to him being a lawyer.
But he deals with anger issues and racism on a daily basis.
This part of the scene starts with Jory catching Isaac and Emily kissing.
However, Amir does not believe Jory and is in complete disbelief.
Excuse me(p. 71, l. 31) underlines that statement.
On the one hand you could think that Amir just trusts Emily to not cheating on him, but knowing that their relationship is breaking apart, it is not very likely.
On the other hand, something more likely, is that Amir just does not want to believe that they have an affair.
Adding to that Jory already destroyed his job, so why not also his marriage (p. 72, ll. 18f.).
Adding to the job, Amir is very upset about the fact that Jory got the promotion and not him.
He argues that he put way more work into the job to be where he is now and has a lot more work moral than Jory (p. 72, ll. 22-29), who still leaves work earlier than Amir (p. 72, l. 29).
At the end he insults Jory with a racial slur (p. 72, l. 29), which underlines the fact that the firm is not racist in general, but just against people with an Islamic background.
After a heated argument between Amir and Isaac (p. 72, ll. 30-37), Amir spits in IsaacsIsaac's face.
His mother did the same when his first crush was a Jewish girl.
She told him to never forget what the jews did and to be proud to be a muslimMuslim.
The fact that Amir spat Isaac in the face shows that he did not forget what his mother once told him.
Furthermore, Jory told Amir that she got the caseload of Mort and not him.
Jory tells him that Mort called him duplicitous (p. 73, l. 7) and impossible to trust (p. 73, ll. 8f.).
Which also attributes to the anger Amir has.
Adding, Amir has plenty of anger building up inside of him.
This gets clear, because Amir drinks alcoholic drinks every day and once smashed a whiskey glasglass out of rage.
He always tries to ignore these feelings, but the inward spiral gets deeper every day (p. 73, ll. 16f.).
As Amir beats up Emily he is in rage and every racist thing she ever did comes up.
She painted him as a slave (scene 1), embarrassed him in front of Isaac and Jory (scene 3) and because of Emily he lost his promotion (scene 1 and 2).
Then after Emily admitted cheating on him, Amir can notcannot control himself anymore.
Only after several punches Amir realized what he has done and know that not Jory destroyed everything, but he did (p. 72, ll. 18f. and p. 74, l. 15).
Looking at the big picture, Amir is very insecure, sad and vulnerable.
He has to deal with racism and islamophobia every day and even changed his name because of that.

But Amir is ashamed and scared to let those feelings speak to him and because he always bottles them up, he sees no other option than letting them out all at once, which concludes in beating Emily up (p. 74, l. 5).
Him being vulnerable shows when he asked, if Emily is sleeping with with Isaac (p. 73, l. 27).
Amir does not want to believe it and it makes him sad just thinking about it.
To conclude, Amir is a guy with a lot of facettesfacets.
He is ashamed of his emotions and ethniticethnic identity.

Amir's character explains how as a person with an Islamic ethnicity it is impossible to be openly proud of his origin and, if you are honest to yourself and others, it is impossible to be an accepted part of the US society.
